title: Which Is Normal?
question_text:
Which of the sampling distributions involving sample means will be approximately normal?

I. A sample of size $n = 55$ from a population that is strongly skewed right.
II. A sample of size $n = 20$ from a population that is slightly skewed right with no outliers.
III. A sample of size $n = 5$ from a population that is roughly normal.
solution:
Statement I is roughly normal; the central limit theorem states sampling distributions will be roughly normal if the sample is large enough, say greater than 30, no matter what the population looks like.

Statement II is roughly normal; samples of size between n=10 and n=29 will be roughly normal as long as the sample shows no strong skewness or outliers.

Statement III is roughly normal; samples of any size will be roughly normal if the parent population is normal.

Keep in mind that cutoffs of sample size such as 10
, 29
, or 30
are not necessarily special; as sample sizes get larger, the sampling distribution gradually becomes closer to normal.

Thus, the correct answer is Choice 'E'.
